title: Laboratory Maintenance of the Chytrid Fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis
procedures:
This protocol outlines the method for thawing Bd from frozen stocks to have cultures in the lab. All steps except for centrifugation should be performed in a biosafety cabinet to both contain and maintain the sterility of the culture. Be sure to spray items with 70% ethanol before placing into the biosafety cabinet to ensure sterility of the culture is maintained.
Materials
Frozen Bd JEL423 stock (frozen in 10% DMSO; initial cultures from Collection of Zoosporic Eufungi, University of Michigan: https://czeum.herb.lsa.umich.edu/[href=https://czeum.herb.lsa.umich.edu/])
1% tryptone, sterile (MilliporeSigma, T7293)
70% ethanol solution (for decontaminating supplies and flow hood)
50-ml conical tubes, sterile (Eppendorf, 0030122178)
Laminar flow hood (BSC Class II or equivalent)
Tissue culture microscope (such as Nikon Eclipse Ts2)
Centrifuge and adaptors for use with 50-ml tubes (such as Centrifuge 5415R, Eppendorf, 5401000137)
Tissue culture treated culture flasks with vent cap, sterile (Cell Treat, 229331, 229341, or 229351)
1.5-ml centrifuge tubes, sterile (Eppendorf, 022363204)
20- to 200-μl micropipet (such as Eppendorf, 3123000055)
2- to 20-μl micropipet (such as Eppendorf, 3123000039)
Filter tips for micropipets, sterile (such as USA Scientific, 1122-1830)
Pipet controller (Drummond Scientific, 4-000-100 or equivalent)
Serological pipets, sterile
Neubauer-improved hemocytometer (such as Thermo Fisher Scientific, 02-671-51B)
NOTE: All solutions and equipment coming into contact with cells must be sterile. Appropriate sterile technique and biosafety flow hood should be used.
1. Thaw 1 ml frozen Bd by swirling tube in a lukewarm water bath.
2. Spray tube and other necessary items with 70% ethanol and place in BSC.
3. Use a pipet to add contents of tube to 9 ml 1% tryptone in a 50-ml conical tube.
4. Rinse cryotube with an additional 1 ml 1% tryptone to gather any remaining cells, adding this to the volume from step 2.

5. Spin cells down at 2,500 × g for 5 min to separate DMSO-containing medium from cells.
6. Pour off supernatant and resuspend cells in 10 ml 1% tryptone.
7. Prepare a 1:10 dilution (10 μl cells, 90 μl medium) of zoospores from the resuspended Bd into a 1.5-ml centrifuge tube.
8. Count the number of cells in the diluted aliquot using a hemocytometer and determine the density of resuspended cells in the conical tube.
9. Add appropriate volumes of resuspended cells and new medium into a 25-cm2 TC-treated culture flask at a final concentration of 2 × 105 cells/ml in 10 ml.
10. Check under microscope daily to assess activity level.
Cells may take up to 1 week to become active enough to begin regular subculturing. Typically, multiple swimming zoospores per fields of view is sufficient.

It is often advantageous to synchronize cultures to ensure that cells harvested for experiments are at a similar stage of development. This helps to minimize variability within a sample. This protocol outlines how to obtain a synchronized culture of Bd in liquid medium. All steps except for centrifugation should be performed in a biosafety cabinet to both contain and maintain the sterility of the culture. Be sure to spray items with 70% ethanol before placing into the biosafety cabinet to ensure sterility of the culture is maintained.
Materials
Active, asynchronous Bd JEL423 culture (Collection of Zoosporic Eufungi, University of Michigan: https://czeum.herb.lsa.umich.edu/[href=https://czeum.herb.lsa.umich.edu/])
1% tryptone, sterile (MilliporeSigma, T7293)
70% ethanol solution (for decontaminating supplies and flow hood)
50-ml conical tubes, sterile (Eppendorf, 0030122178)
Laminar flow hood (BSC Class II or equivalent)
Tissue culture microscope (such as Nikon Eclipse Ts2)
Centrifuge and adaptors for use with 50-ml tubes (such as Centrifuge 5415R, Eppendorf, 5401000137)
Tissue culture treated culture flasks with vent cap, sterile (Cell Treat, 229331, 229341, or 229351)
Steriflip filters, 20 μm (MilliporeSigma, SCNY00020)
1.5-ml centrifuge tubes, sterile (Eppendorf, 022363204)
20- to 200-μl micropipet (such as Eppendorf, 3123000055)
2- to 20-μl micropipet (such as Eppendorf, 3123000039)
Filter tips for the micropipets, sterile (such as USA Scientific, 1122-1830)
Pipet controller (Drummond Scientific, 4-000-100 or equivalent)
Serological pipets, sterile
Neubauer-improved hemocytometer (such as Thermo Fisher Scientific, 02-671-51B)
NOTE: All solutions and equipment coming into contact with cells must be sterile. Appropriate sterile technique and biosafety flow hood should be used.
1. To achieve a synchronous culture, filter the asynchronous culture through a 20-μm Steriflip filter into a 50-ml conical tube.
2. Prepare a 1:10 dilution (10 μl cells, 90 μl medium) of the filtered zoospores into a 1.5-ml centrifuge tube.

3. Add appropriate volumes of filtered cells and new medium into a 25-cm2 TC-treated culture flask at a final concentration of 2 × 105 cells/ml in 10 ml.
If necessary, use centrifugation to concentrate filtered cells, resuspend, recount, and then recalculate the necessary volume needed to reach 2 × 105 cells/ml.
4. Incubate flask at 24˚C, subculturing to a new flask every 3 days (see Basic Protocol 3[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.309#cpz1309-prot-0003]).

This protocol outlines how to maintain a synchronized culture of Bd in liquid medium. It is essential to seed Bd at the appropriate density: If the culture is too sparse, sporangia may fail to release zoospores; if it is too dense, cells will fail to develop (Fig. 2[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.309#cpz1309-fig-0002]). We usually seed cells in flasks at ∼2 × 105 cells/ml with a final volume of 10 ml for a 25-cm2 flask; 25 ml for a 75-cm2 flask; and 60 ml for a 175-cm2 flask. Note that because Bd is a deadly pathogen to amphibians we typically treat it as a BSL-II organism and conduct cell culture in a laminar flow biosafety cabinet. We also autoclave or treat with freshly diluted 10% bleach all items that come in contact with cultures, including tissue culture plastics.

Figure 2 Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis zoospore densities over time in liquid culture. Densities of zoospores in suspension over the 3-day lifecycle of B. dendrobatidis (Bd) when seeded at the given concentrations. Insets show cartoon side views of a hypothetical flask (top) and top-view phase contrast images (bottom) of a flask seeded at 2 × 105 cells/ml at the given time points. Hemocytometer counts are not always reliable when counting Bd zoospores but due to the size of the cells, it is the best option we have. A number of factors could explain unexpected cell counts, such as too few or too many cells per hemocytometer grid (most manufacturers recommend counting 20-200 cells total per grid) or sporangia actively releasing zoospores into the aliquot used for counting. It is typical to see varied curves as shown here. Materials Active, synchronous culture of Bd JEL423 in liquid medium (see Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.309#cpz1309-prot-0001] and Basic Protocol 2[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.309#cpz1309-prot-0002]) Tryptone liquid medium, sterile (1%, w/v, MilliporeSigma, T7293; see recipe[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.309#cpz1309-rec-0004])

70% ethanol solution (for decontaminating supplies and flow hood)
Laminar flow hood (BSC Class II or equivalent)
Tissue culture microscope (such as Nikon Eclipse Ts2)
TC-treated culture flasks with vent cap, sterile (Cell Treat, 229331, 229341, or 229351)
1.5-ml centrifuge tubes, sterile (Eppendorf, 022363204)
20- to 200-μl micropipet (such as Eppendorf, 3123000055)
2- to 20-μl micropipet (such as Eppendorf, 3123000039)
Filter tips for the micropipets, sterile (such as USA Scientific, 1122-1830)
Pipet controller (Drummond Scientific, 4-000-100 or equivalent)
Serological pipets, sterile
Neubauer-improved hemocytometer (such as Thermo Fisher Scientific, 02-671-51B)
Centrifuge and adaptors for use with 50-ml tubes (such as Centrifuge 5415R, Eppendorf, 5401000137)
NOTE: All solutions and equipment coming into contact with cells must be sterile. Appropriate sterile technique and biosafety flow hood should be used.
1. After thawing Bd (see Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.309#cpz1309-prot-0001]) and synchronizing the culture (see Basic Protocol 2[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.309#cpz1309-prot-0002]), transfer (or “subculture”) the cells to new medium every 3 days as follows.
See Supporting Information Figure 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.309#support-information-section] for a calendar layout of subculturing timeline.
2. Prepare a 1:10 dilution of zoospores in suspension from a 3-day-old flask of Bd into a 1.5-ml centrifuge tube by removing 10 μl medium from the mature culture flask and adding to 90 μl medium in a 1.5-ml centrifuge tube. Gently flick tube to mix.
3. Count cell density in the diluted aliquot using a hemocytometer; determine the density of cells in the flask using the appropriate formula.
4. Add appropriate volumes of cells from the 3-day-old flask and new medium to subculture into a new flask at a final concentration of 2 × 105 cells/ml.

For example: If the 3-day-old flask has a zoospore density of 4 × 106 cells/ml, put 0.5 ml (2 × 106 cells) of mature culture into 9.5 ml of 1% tryptone medium for a 25-cm2 TC-treated flask. The final concentration of cells in the flask is now 2 × 105 cells/ml.
5. Close the cap of the flask, gently lay it on its flat side, and grow at 24˚C for 3 days.

Bd can be cultured asynchronously, though the culture will be less predictable. Maintaining an asynchronous culture requires daily observation of flasks and is difficult to determine cell density. Subculturing would take place as needed or when the flask becomes too dense by eye.
Additional Materials (see also Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.309#cpz1309-prot-0001])
Non-TC-treated culture flasks with vent cap, sterile (Cell Treat, 229500, 229510, or 229520)
1. After thawing Bd into a non-TC-treated flask (see Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.309#cpz1309-prot-0001]), transfer (or “subculture”) the cells to new medium as needed, as follows.
2. Prepare a 1:10 and 1:20 dilution of the mature cells into new medium in a non-TC-treated flask.
For example, add 1 ml of cell culture into 9 ml of 1% tryptone medium for a 25-cm2 non-TC-treated flask for the 1:10 dilution.
3. Close the cap of the flasks, gently lay on their flat sides, and grow at 24˚C until culture becomes too dense and needs to be sub-cultured again.
Check on flasks daily. The appropriate density for maintenance depends on the age of individual cells and is best empirically determined for each laboratory by splitting at regular intervals at different densities and identifying the parameters that give predictable and robust growth. We recommend starting with passaging at 1:10 and 1:20 every 3 days and, depending on cell growth, adjust concentrations and/or passaging frequency as needed. If the culture remains sparse, try subculturing at higher cell density and/or less frequently. If cells are too dense and stop growing, try subculturing at lower cell density and/or more frequently. Cultures may appear similar to those shown in Figure 1B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.309#cpz1309-fig-0001].

This protocol outlines how to maintain Bd on agar plates, which can be helpful for isolation of individual colonies. All steps except for centrifugation should be performed in a biosafety cabinet to both contain and maintain the sterility of the culture. Be sure to spray items with 70% ethanol before placing into the biosafety cabinet to ensure sterility of the culture is maintained.
Materials
Active, healthy culture of Bd JEL423 (Collection of Zoosporic Eufungi, University of Michigan: https://czeum.herb.lsa.umich.edu/[href=https://czeum.herb.lsa.umich.edu/])
Solid medium (1% tryptone, MilliporeSigma, T7293; 1.5% agar, Thermo Fisher Scientific, BP1423)
Dilute Salts (DS) solution (see recipe[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.309#cpz1309-rec-0001])
Laminar flow hood (BSC Class II or equivalent)
Tissue culture microscope (such as Nikon Eclipse Ts2)
Neubauer-improved hemocytometer (such as Thermo Fisher Scientific, 02-671-51B)
1.5-ml centrifuge tubes, sterile (Eppendorf, 022363204)
1,000-μl micropipet (such as Eppendorf, 3124000121)
20- to 200-μl micropipet (such as Eppendorf, 3123000055)
2- to 20-μl micropipet (such as Eppendorf, 3123000039)
Filter tips for micropipets, sterile (such as USA Scientific, 1122-1830)
Glass beads, sterile (for spreading)
NOTE: All solutions and equipment coming into contact with cells must be sterile. Appropriate sterile technique and biosafety flow hood should be used.
1. Collect zoospores from a plate of actively growing Bd.
Use the 1-ml micropipet to distribute 1 ml of DS over the plate, tilted at ∼45° to pool released zoospores at the bottom of the plate and collect the liquid into a 1.5-ml centrifuge tube.
2. Take 10 μl of the liquid and count zoospores using a hemocytometer; determine the density of cells in the flask using the appropriate formula.
If necessary, prepare a 1:10 dilution (10 μl cells, 90 μl medium) of the harvested zoospores into a 1.5-ml centrifuge tube.
3. Dilute cells to a final concentration between 2 × 106 and 2 × 107 cells/ml in 1 ml DS.

If necessary, use centrifugation to concentrate cells, resuspend, recount, and then recalculate the necessary volume needed to reach between 2 × 106 and 2 × 107 cells/ml.
4. Add 1 ml diluted cells to a new 1% tryptone plate.
The concentration of cells is now between 2 × 106 and 2 × 107 cells/plate, as the volume changes by an indeterminate amount when you place the cells onto the agar.
5. Gently shake the new plate to spread the liquid around the agar.
Shake the plate gently, rotate it ∼90˚, and shake again, continuing this process until all dry areas of the plate are gone.
Sterile, glass beads may also be used to spread the cells around the plate.
6. Incubate plates at 24˚C.
Plates may also be grown at room temperature.
Plates do not need to be sealed but may be sealed with Parafilm to prevent plates from drying out.
Plates may also be kept inside plastic containers with ∼10 ml of water in a beaker to prevent plates from drying out.
7. Transfer cells to new plates every 3 days to keep the culture healthy.

Although preparing solid medium is more time consuming than preparing liquid medium, growing Bd on plates has several advantages, for example, easier detection of a contaminated culture. (See Commentary, Background Information for more detail.)
Additional Materials (see also Basic Protocol 3[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.309#cpz1309-prot-0003])
Active, healthy liquid culture of Bd JEL423 (Collection of Zoosporic Eufungi, University of Michigan: https://czeum.herb.lsa.umich.edu/[href=https://czeum.herb.lsa.umich.edu/])
1. Prepare a 1:10 dilution (10 μl cells, 90 μl medium) of zoospores from a 3-day flask into a 1.5-ml centrifuge tube.
2. Count zoospores from diluted aliquot using a hemocytometer; determine density of cells in the 3-day-old flask.
3. Dilute cells to between 2 × 106 and 2 × 107 cells/ml in 1 ml DS.
If necessary, use centrifugation to concentrate cells, resuspend, recount, and then recalculate the necessary volume needed to reach between 2 × 106 and 2 × 107cells/ml.
4. Add 1 ml diluted cells to a new 1% tryptone plate.
The concentration of cells is now between 2 × 106 and 2 × 107 cells/plate, as the volume changes by an indeterminate amount when you place the cells onto the agar.
5. Gently shake the new plate to spread the liquid around the agar.
Shake the plate gently, rotate it, and shake again, continuing this process until all dry areas of the plate are gone.
Sterile, glass beads may also be used to spread the cells around the plate.
6. Incubate plates at 24˚C.
7. Check on plates daily to assess activity levels, ensuring zoospores are present and mobile.
Cells that have been growing in liquid culture for a while may take several weeks to adjust to growing on plates.
8. Transfer cells to new plates every 3 days to keep the culture healthy.

The following method is adapted from Boyle et al. (2003[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.309#cpz1309-bib-0002]), which involves slow freezing of ampules of cells resuspended in a cryopreservant and long-term storage in liquid nitrogen or at -80°C. All steps except for centrifugation should be performed in a biosafety cabinet to both contain and maintain the sterility of the culture. Be sure to spray items with 70% ethanol before placing into the biosafety cabinet to ensure sterility of the culture is maintained. We recommend cryopreserving multiple vials in parallel and testing the viability of the cultures by reviving one vial after at least 2 weeks of cryostorage.
Materials
Active, healthy culture of Bd JEL423 (Collection of Zoosporic Eufungi, University of Michigan: https://czeum.herb.lsa.umich.edu/[href=https://czeum.herb.lsa.umich.edu/]) grown in a non-TC-treated flask
Cryopreservation medium: Sterile 1% tryptone (MilliporeSigma, T7293), 10% sterile DMSO (MilliporeSigma, D2650)
70% ethanol solution (for decontaminating supplies and flow hood)
Laminar flow hood (BSC Class II or equivalent)
Tissue culture microscope (such as Nikon Eclipse Ts2)
50-ml conical tubes, sterile (Eppendorf, 0030122178)
Centrifuge and adaptors for use with 50-ml tubes (such as Centrifuge 5415R, Eppendorf, 5401000137)
Cryovials with rubber gaskets, sterile (Corning, 431416)
Mr. Frosty isopropanol container (Thermo Fisher Scientific, 5100-0001)
Neubauer-improved hemocytometer
-80°C freezer
Liquid nitrogen freezer
NOTE: All solutions and equipment coming into contact with cells must be sterile. Appropriate sterile technique and biosafety flow hood should be used.
1. Remove cells from culture flask and transfer to a 50-ml conical centrifuge tube.
Hold flask upright and smack the side of the flask to dislodge any adhered sporangia.
2. Centrifuge cells at 2,500 × g for 5 min; remove supernatant.
3. Resuspend cells in 5 ml cryopreservation medium pre-chilled to 4°C.
4. Aliquot 1 ml cells into labeled cryovials.
5. Transfer vials to pre-chilled (4°C) Mr. Frosty isopropanol container and store container in -80°C freezer.

The use of the Mr. Frosty container is key to maintaining the viability of cultures through the cryopreservation process. Stocks may be kept at -80°C for short-term storage (up to 6 months), but if you plan on storing your stocks long term (longer than 6 months), transfer tubes from the -80°C to liquid nitrogen after 24-48 hr to ensure stable temperatures and prevent thawing.
